about.tagline: Building at the intersection of cryptographic systems, distributed infrastructure, and modern software engineering.
about.bio: I am a self-driven engineer with an unconventional but deliberate path. My academic background spans accounting, music education, and a Master's in Arts & Cultural Management — disciplines that sharpened my analytical thinking, structured creativity, and ability to communicate complex ideas with clarity. In 2024, I completed the ALX Software Engineering Programme with a specialisation in back-end development, formalising years of self-taught systems work into a rigorous professional foundation. Today, I focus on blockchain infrastructure and fullstack development, working from first principles — implementing cryptographic primitives, building Bitcoin and Ethereum toolkits from scratch, and orchestrating multi-node distributed systems. I bring to every project the same discipline I applied to music theory and the same precision I cultivated in accounting: nothing is taken for granted, everything is understood.

projects.title: Bitcoin Dev Kit
projects.summary: A full Bitcoin development toolkit built from first principles — covering node infrastructure, wallet derivation, raw transaction construction, and a React block explorer dashboard.
projects.description: The Bitcoin Dev Kit is a modular, production-grade toolkit for interacting with the Bitcoin protocol at every layer. The core module implements BIP-39 mnemonic generation and AES-128 encryption, BIP-32 master key and hardened/normal child key derivation verified against official test vectors, and BIP-44 hierarchical deterministic wallet paths. The transaction engine constructs legacy raw transactions from scratch — serialising TxInput and TxOutput objects with correct varint encoding, SIGHASH flags, and little-endian byte ordering. A Python RPC client exposes the full Bitcoin Core JSON-RPC API surface. The Bitcoin node is containerised with Docker, fronted by an Nginx load balancer, and supports all network modes (mainnet, testnet3, testnet4, regtest, signet). The React + Vite GUI connects to the live node and renders real-time blockchain data through a dashboard block explorer. All modules are covered by pytest suites with deterministic known-vector assertions.
highlights: BIP-32/39/44 HD wallet derivation implemented from scratch against official test vectors
Raw Bitcoin transaction serialization at byte level with full SIGHASH type support
Dockerised Bitcoin Core node with Nginx load balancer across all network modes
React + Vite block explorer dashboard connected to live Bitcoin RPC
Full pytest coverage with cryptographic known-vector validation

projects.title: Ethereum Dev Kit
projects.summary: A complete Ethereum development toolkit covering post-merge node infrastructure, HD wallet derivation, ABI encoding, and multi-type transaction construction — all implemented from the ground up.
projects.description: The Ethereum Dev Kit mirrors and extends the Bitcoin Dev Kit with full coverage of the Ethereum protocol stack. The crypto module implements Keccak-256 hashing, EIP-55 checksummed address derivation, ABI function selector and event topic encoding — all without relying on high-level frameworks. The wallet engine applies the same BIP-32/39/44 derivation pipeline, sharing test vectors with the Bitcoin kit to validate cross-chain consistency. The transaction engine constructs all three Ethereum transaction types: legacy (Type 0), EIP-2930 access list (Type 1), and EIP-1559 dynamic fee (Type 2) — including ETH transfers, contract deployments, and contract interactions. The node infrastructure runs a post-merge Ethereum stack with Geth (execution layer) and Prysm (consensus layer) communicating via JWT authentication over the Engine API. An Nginx load balancer sits in front of the RPC endpoint. The React + Vite frontend renders an Ethereum block explorer dashboard. Python and JavaScript RPC clients are both fully tested.
highlights: Post-merge Ethereum node: Geth (EL) + Prysm (CL) with JWT Engine API authentication
All three Ethereum transaction types constructed from scratch (Type 0, 1, 2)
Keccak-256, EIP-55 checksum addresses, ABI function selectors and event topics
BIP-32/39/44 wallet derivation shared with Bitcoin kit and validated against same test vectors
React + Vite Ethereum block explorer with live RPC integration

projects.title: Multichain Block Explorer
projects.summary: A production-style fullstack application that unifies Bitcoin and Ethereum node data behind a single Flask API and React dashboard — fully orchestrated with Docker Compose.
projects.description: The Multichain Block Explorer is the capstone project that brings the Bitcoin and Ethereum dev kits together into a single, deployable fullstack application. The Python/Flask backend exposes a unified REST API with separate controller and routing layers, proxying requests to both Bitcoin Core and Ethereum (Geth) nodes through dedicated blockchain client modules. The React + Vite frontend renders independent Bitcoin and Ethereum block explorer views within a shared dashboard layout, fetching data from the Flask backend rather than directly from nodes. The infrastructure layer orchestrates five Docker services: the Flask application server (served via Gunicorn), the Bitcoin Core node, the Ethereum execution node (Geth), the Ethereum consensus node (Prysm), and an Nginx load balancer routing all traffic. Both Python and JavaScript RPC clients are covered by independent test suites. The project demonstrates end-to-end system design from protocol-level node communication through API design to polished frontend delivery.
highlights: Unified REST API aggregating live Bitcoin and Ethereum node data
Five-service Docker Compose stack: Flask, Bitcoin node, Geth, Prysm, Nginx
Separated controller/route architecture in Flask backend
Dual-chain React dashboard with Bitcoin and Ethereum explorer views
Independent test suites for Python (pytest) and JavaScript (Vitest) RPC clients

projects.title: Embedded Workbench
projects.summary: A containerised embedded development environment covering hardware programming, protocol analysis, and device monitoring across a wide range of microcontrollers, FPGAs, and single-board computers.
projects.description: The Embedded Workbench is a self-contained, Dockerised workspace designed to make embedded development fully reproducible and portable. It is divided into three functional layers: hardware programming (PlatformIO for Arduino, ESP32, and STM32; native toolchain for PIC; Xilinx Spartan-6 FPGA; Raspberry Pi), hardware analysis (GPIO/UART/I2C/SPI logic analyser, USB/UART/JTAG/SWD monitor, network packet monitor, software-defined radio capture), and hardware access (Android via raw ADB toolchain — compiling and deploying APKs without Android Studio; cross-platform stubs for iOS, Linux, macOS, Windows). Each environment runs in a privileged Docker container with direct device passthrough via udev, host networking for OpenOCD and GDB debugging, and SSH access for remote development. The project demonstrates the breadth of hardware knowledge underpinning the software and blockchain work.
highlights: Dockerised toolchains for PlatformIO (Arduino, ESP32, STM32), PIC compiler, and FPGA
Hardware analysis containers with GPIO, UART, I2C, SPI, JTAG, SWD, SDR, and network monitoring
Android app development from raw toolchain — no Android Studio, direct ADB deployment
Privileged Docker containers with udev hot-plug, host networking, and SSH access
Fully reproducible embedded environments across any Linux host

projects.title: Language Workbench
projects.summary: A containerised polyglot programming environment with working reference implementations across thirteen languages and architectures — from high-level scripting to bare-metal assembly.
projects.description: The Language Workbench is a personal engineering environment built for deep, first-principles fluency across programming languages and architectures. It houses working implementations in Python, JavaScript, Java, C, C++, C#, Go, Rust, PHP, Bash, and three assembly dialects — x86-64, ARM, and RISC-V. Each language lives in a dedicated source file within a shared Docker container, giving a single, reproducible workspace for cross-language experimentation and reference. A Makefile-driven build system allows running any language with a single command. The project reflects a philosophy of understanding the full stack from register-level computation to high-level abstractions — the same philosophy that drives writing Bitcoin transaction serialisation or Ethereum ABI encoding from scratch rather than reaching for a library.
highlights: Working implementations in 13 languages: Python, JS, Java, C, C++, C#, Go, Rust, PHP, Bash, x86-64, ARM, RISC-V
Single Dockerised environment with Makefile-driven build for all languages
Covers the full stack from assembly to scripting languages
Foundation for the low-level intuition demonstrated in blockchain and embedded projects
